sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of calcium chloride (CaCl2)?
message_2:
To find the molar mass of calcium chloride (CaCl2), we need to determine the molar mass of each element in the compound and then add them together.

Calcium (Ca) has a molar mass of 40.08 g/mol.
Chlorine (Cl) has a molar mass of 35.45 g/mol.

Since there are two chlorine atoms in calcium chloride, we need to multiply the molar mass of chlorine by 2:

Molar mass of 2 Cl atoms = 2 Ã— 35.45 g/mol = 70.90 g/mol

Now, add the molar mass of calcium and the molar mass of the two chlorine atoms:

Molar mass of CaCl2 = 40.08 g/mol (Ca) + 70.90 g/mol (2 Cl) = 110.98 g/mol

So, the molar mass of calcium chloride (CaCl2) is 110.98 g/mol.
